name: Avoid HTTP response splitting
associatedValueName: Call stack from user input source down to the target HTML user output method
description:
This quality rule identifies vulnerabilities where applications fail to properly neutralize Carriage Return (CR, \r) and Line Feed (LF, \n) characters in user input before incorporating it into HTTP headers. The rule detects data flow paths from user input sources to HTTP header operations, identifying potential response splitting vulnerabilities.
Using CAST's data-flow engine, this rule traces untrusted data from entry points (request parameters, form data, etc.) to HTTP header manipulation methods.
output:
List all methods that make resource calls forged by user input

It provides the following information:
- The full name of the method that calls the user input method.
- Call stack from user input source down to the target method (Header manipulation method).
rationale:
HTTP Response Splitting occurs when an attacker can inject CR/LF characters into HTTP headers, allowing them to:
-Control subsequent headers: inject malicious headers by terminating the current header line
-Manipulate the response body: insert arbitrary content after the headers section
-Create additional HTTP responses: craft completely separate responses under their control
-Enable cache poisoning: manipulate cached responses to affect other users
-Facilitate cross-site scripting (XSS): inject malicious scripts into the response
The vulnerability exploits the HTTP protocol's reliance on CR/LF sequences to separate headers and terminate the header section, potentially compromising the entire HTTP response structure.

remediation: To prevent HTTP Response Splitting vulnerabilities, use safe APIs: utilize framework-provided methods that automatically handle sanitization.
alternativeName: Ensure your application does not execute HTTP requests without sanitization
